text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zimbabwean press on Friday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Officials confiscated a 275-kg (600-pound) consignment of marijuana on Zimbabwe's national cargo carrier Affretair at Amsterdam's Schipol airport. They said the shipment appeared to be part of a "well-organised" drug export operation.

- A U.S.-listed mining company, Casmyn Corp, is considering parallel listing in Zimbabwe this year, its president, chairman and chief executive Amyn Dahya said in London. The Nevada-based company owns 100 percent of the Turk mine in Zimbabwe.

- Commercial production of platinum at Zimbabwe's Hartley Mine has been deferred for six months because of a number of problems which have increased the initial investment capital budget to about Z$2.9 billion. The mine is a joint venture between Australian mining giants Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd and Delta Gold NL.

- Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe said black commercial farmers who do not fully use their farms risked losing them, because the government's acquisition of under-used land was not confined to white-owned properties.
- Ten people were killed and 87 others hurt in 163 vehicle crashes around Zimbabwe on New Year's Eve and January 1, police said.
- More than 163,000 tourists visited Zimbabwe during the just-ended Christmas holidays.
